purpose: To outline the methodology for developing, validating, and implementing a
macroeconomic overlay model for IFRS 9 compliance.
key_topics: To outline the methodology for developing, validating, and implementing a
macroeconomic overlay model for IFRS 9 compliance.

purpose: To state the document's primary purpose: outlining the methodology for a
macroeconomic overlay model to produce Point-in-Time (PIT) PDs for IFRS 9.
To establish the objective of creating a robust and transparent framework for
estimating 12-month and lifetime PIT PDs.
key_topics: This section sets the stage. It will clearly state that the document's
primary purpose is to outline the methodology for developing, validating,
and implementing a macroeconomic overlay model. This model will adjust
the bank's existing Through-the-Cycle (TTC) or hybrid Probability of
Default (PD) estimates to produce Point-in-Time (PIT), forward-looking
PDs compliant with IFRS 9 standards. It should explicitly state the
objective: to create a robust, auditable, and transparent framework for
estimating 12-month and lifetime PIT PDs.

purpose: To define the precise boundaries of the methodology.
key_topics: This section defines the precise boundaries of the methodology. It will
specify which portfolios the model applies to (e.g., corporate, SME,
specific retail segments), the geographical regions covered (e.g., EU,
specific countries), and any material exposures that are explicitly
excluded from this methodology and why.

purpose: To anchor the methodology in its IFRS 9 context by detailing the specific
requirements the model is designed to meet.
key_topics: This section anchors the methodology in its IFRS 9 context. It will detail
the specific IFRS 9 requirements that the model is designed to meet,
including the need for unbiased, the use of reasonable and supportable
forward-looking information, and the ability to generate a PD term
structure (12-month and lifetime). Each requirement should be explained
with a brief description of how this methodology addresses it.

purpose: To establish the economic rationale and high-level modeling approach for the
macroeconomic overlay.
key_topics: Conceptual Link Between Macroeconomy and PDs
Rationale for a Macro Overlay Approach
Overlay Model Options
Novel Risks

table_of_contents.heading_label: Conceptual Link Between Macroeconomy and PDs
purpose: To establish the economic rationale behind the model by describing how
macroeconomic factors influence corporate default risk.
key_topics: This section establishes the economic rationale behind the model. It will
describe the theoretical transmission channels through which macroeconomic
factors (like GDP growth, unemployment, interest rates) are expected to
influence corporate default risk. Channels to discuss include the
revenue/cash flow channel, asset value/collateral channel, and credit
supply/financial conditions channel. This demonstrates that the model is
based on sound economic principles, not just statistical correlation.

table_of_contents.heading_label: Rationale for a Macro Overlay Approach
purpose: To justify the choice of an overlay (or 'satellite model') approach instead
of redeveloping the core PD models from scratch.
key_topics: This section justifies the choice of an overlay (or 'satellite model')
approach instead of redeveloping the core PD models from scratch. It will
argue that this approach allows for the re-use of well-validated TTC
components, ensures faster implementation, and maintains consistency with
the Basel regulatory framework while satisfying IFRS 9's PIT requirements.
It explains the decomposition of the final PIT PD into PIT PD =
f(TTC PD, Macro-economic Overlay).

purpose: To provide a high-level survey of potential modeling techniques to show that
a thoughtful selection process was undertaken.
key_topics: This section provides a high-level survey of potential modeling techniques
for the overlay. It will briefly introduce and compare different model
families (e.g., regression-based models like GLM or OLS, autoregressive
models, survival analysis, machine learning models). The purpose is to
show that a thoughtful selection process was undertaken before settling on
a final approach.

purpose: To address the challenge of modeling risks lacking historical precedent
and not captured by traditional macroeconomic variables.
key_topics: This section addresses the modeling challenge posed by novel and emerging
risks not adequately represented in historical datasets. It will outline
the framework's approach to incorporating factors like climate change risks
(both physical and transition), pandemic-related economic disruptions, and
significant geopolitical shifts. The discussion will cover the use of
qualitative overlays, where expert judgment is applied to adjust model
outputs based on specific forward-looking narratives. It will also explore
the use of scenario analysis with bespoke assumptions and the search for
appropriate proxy variables to ensure the framework remains robust and
responsive to an evolving risk landscape.

purpose: To detail the data sources, quality assurance processes, and the final
sample construction for model development.
key_topics: Source Inventory
Data Quality Assessment
Segmentation Development Sample Definition

purpose: To list the internal and external data sources used in model development.
key_topics: This section lists typical data used in the model development. It will detail
internal data sources (e.g., default data, loan characteristics, TTC PDs
from the data warehouse) and external data sources (e.g., macroeconomic
variables from central banks, statistical offices, or third-party
providers like Bloomberg).

purpose: To detail the steps taken to ensure all data is fit for purpose.
key_topics: This section details the steps taken to ensure data is fit for purpose. It
will describe checks for completeness, accuracy, and consistency. It will
also outline the preferred treatment of missing values (e.g., imputation
methods), outliers, and any structural breaks identified in the time series
(e.g., due to macropolitical changes or major economic events).

purpose: To describe the construction of the dataset used for modeling.
key_topics: This section describes the construction of the dataset used for modeling. It
will define the criteria for including a obligor in the sample, the
observation period (e.g., Jan 2005 - Dec 2023), and the unit of
observation (e.g., obligor-month). It will also justify any segmentation
of the portfolio (e.g., by industry, geography, or rating level) for
developing separate models if needed.

purpose: To document the process of preparing and analyzing the macroeconomic data
prior to variable selection and modeling.
key_topics: Long List of Variables
Common Transformations
Analysis of Macro Variables

purpose: To compile and justify a comprehensive 'long-list' of candidate
macroeconomic variables grounded in economic theory.
key_topics: The selection process begins by compiling a comprehensive 'long-list' of
candidate macroeconomic variables. This list is not chosen arbitrarily;
it is grounded in economic theory and empirical evidence, linking directly
to the credit risk transmission channels discussed in Section 2.1. This
section will present the full set of variables initially considered,
grouped by economic category (e.g., Real Economy, Financial Conditions,
Asset Prices), and provide the textbook justification or empirical
rationale for why each was considered a plausible driver of default behavior.

purpose: To document the specific transformations applied to raw data and the
rationale for each.
key_topics: This section documents the specific transformations applied to the raw data.
It will explain the rationale for using lags (to capture delayed effects),
differences or growth rates (to achieve stationarity and capture momentum),
or non-linear transformations (e.g., polynomial terms, splines) to better
capture the relationship between macro-drivers and defaults.

purpose: To explore the statistical properties of the potential explanatory variables
to inform how they should be transformed for modeling.
key_topics: This section explores the potential explanatory variables. It will include
time-series plots, summary statistics, and correlation matrices for the
long-list of macroeconomic variables. The analysis will check for
stationarity (e.g., using ADF tests) and seasonality, which informs how
variables need to be transformed (e.g., using differences, lags, or
growth rates). Present a list statistical and qualitative checks that has
to be performed for each variable.

purpose: To outline the structured process for reducing the long-list of variables
to a final, robust, and parsimonious shortlist for modeling.
key_topics: Initial Screening and Filtering
Desired Short List Properties
Dimensionality Reduction Options

purpose: To compile and justify a comprehensive 'long-list' of candidate
macroeconomic variables grounded in economic theory.
key_topics: The selection process begins by compiling a comprehensive 'long-list' of
candidate macroeconomic variables. This list is not chosen arbitrarily;
it is grounded in economic theory and empirical evidence. This section will
present the full set of variables initially considered, grouped by economic
category (e.g., Real Economy, Financial Conditions, Asset Prices), and
provide the textbook justification or empirical rationale for why each was
considered a plausible driver of default behavior.

purpose: To explain the criteria beyond statistical performance used to select the
final shortlist of variables for the model.
key_topics: Overview: This crucial section explains the criteria used to select the final
shortlist from the statistically significant candidates. A variable's inclusion
is not based on statistical performance alone; it must also satisfy several
practical and qualitative requirements essential for a robust and compliant
IFRS 9 model. This section will detail the desired properties of the final
variable set, including:
 Economic Intuition: The relationship must be logical and explainable.
 Forecast Availability: The variable must be reliably forecastable under
multiple scenarios from an auditable source.
 Stability: The historical relationship should be stable across different
economic regimes.
 Parsimony: The final set should be as simple as possible to avoid overfitting
and enhance interpretability.
 The final combination of variables will be presented here, along with a
concluding rationale for why this set is considered the most robust and
sensible choice.

purpose: To describe the final, structured review process that combines statistical
evidence with expert judgment to select the final variable shortlist.
key_topics: This section describes the crucial final stage of the variable selection
process: the deliberative exercise of moving from the quantitatively
screened list of candidates to the final, parsimonious shortlist used for
model development. This is not a purely mechanical step; it is a
structured, multi-faceted review process that combines statistical evidence
with expert judgment to ensure the final model is robust, sensible, and fit
for purpose under IFRS 9. The outcome is documented in a selection table,
where each candidate variable is scored against the key criteria (e.g.,
statistical power, economic rationale, forecastability, stability). This
creates a transparent audit trail that clearly justifies the final decision,
explaining not only why certain variables were chosen, but also why others
were rejected. The result is a final, defensible shortlist that is
statistically sound, operationally viable, and aligned with the core
principles of IFRS 9.

purpose: To detail the complete process of constructing, specifying, benchmarking,
and evaluating the final macroeconomic overlay model.
key_topics: Challenger Model Development and Benchmarking
Model Specification and Estimation
Model Performance Evaluation

purpose: To ensure the selected model is optimal by developing and benchmarking it
against one or more viable alternative (challenger) models.
key_topics: To ensure the selected model is not just adequate but optimal among viable
alternatives, a challenger model framework is employed. This involves
developing one or more alternative models to compete against the champion.
This process strengthens the final model choice and provides valuable
insights into the stability and sensitivity of different approaches. The
development of challengers is structured around testing different
hypotheses about the underlying data and relationships.

purpose: To detail the final chosen model's mathematical form and report its
estimated parameters and their statistical significance.
key_topics: This section details the final chosen model's mathematical form. It will
present the model equation (e.g., the logistic regression formula), define
all its components, and report the estimated coefficients, their signs, and
statistical significance (p-values). The sign of each coefficient must be
checked for economic intuition.

purpose: To rigorously assess the final model's performance on historical data using
a variety of quantitative metrics.
key_topics: This section rigorously assesses the model's performance on historical data.
It will present key performance metrics for goodness-of-fit (e.g., R-squared,
AUC), accuracy (e.g., Brier score), and stability (e.g., parameter
stability tests across different time periods). The evaluation should be
performed on both the development sample (in-sample) and a holdout sample
(out-of-time) to test for overfitting.
